Linked to systemic dissemination of treponema. A "blooming" rash that progresses in flare-ups.


- Syphilitic roseola: 1st secondary syphilis rash, 6 weeks after the chancroid, pinkish macules on the trunk, no other functional symptoms


- Syphilis :

- Papular: monomorphic, copper-coloured papules, variable number and location

- Palmoplantar: very suggestive ++, copper-coloured erythematous papules on palms and soles, inconstant

- Genital and perineal: painless, non-itchy, multiple, soft, papular/erosive, contagious +++.


- Other cutaneous symptoms: false perlchea, acneiform papules on the chin, mown patches on the tongue, depilation of the eyebrows, etc.


- General and extra-cutaneous-mucosal signs: fever, headaches, poly-ADP, poly-arthralgias, neurosyphilis (ophthalmological manifestations, hypoacusis, tinnitus, facial paralysis, meningitis, etc.).

question.title: What is a characteristic of the cutaneous symptoms of secondary syphilis?

option_a.title: Painless, non-itchy, and multiple, soft, papular/erosive lesions

option_b.title: Fever, headaches, and poly-arthralgias are common symptoms

option_c.title: The rash progresses in flare-ups and is accompanied by systemic symptoms

option_d.title: The lesions are copper-coloured and appear on the palms and soles

correct_option.title: A
correct_option.description: This consists only a letter of the correct option
